document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

FB59E01CE0A7402A826CF02B58FD718E.description:
Sort pictures into categories of biotic (living) and abiotic
(nonliving).

E8B91DDF337A425B85AE1D4CFB8B25E9.description: List the resources in the environment that support living things.

289B198B248948708EE7B766065B8A55.description:
Identify a connection between an abiotic factor and a living
organism in an environment.

2B8C58823B7D42C1A0A2BF2B5ADF950B.description:
Given a series of pictures of environmental changes, identify
them as gradual or sudden.

A90E9213145F411A9D442FC30D3A7343.description:
Sort the effects of a change in an ecosystem as harmful or
beneficial to a population of organisms.

A03B24ED4A84420EBC392C1CE0BE0CA8.description:
Note: Forms of energy are introduced in 3.PS.3.Given a picture
of an ecosystem describe a change that would be beneficial to
an organism and a change that would be harmful.

4B2E0EF166AD4BC0930B7D71EFBE6EFA.description:
Identify that energy can move from place to place. (e.g. measure
the temperature of hot water as it cools on a tabletop and identify
that heat is leaving the water and entering the air).

4C73705AF893443AA2A27ACBA72E94C2.description:
Identify that energy can change from one form to another (e.g,
measure the temperature of a substance (water, air) before
and after the sun shines on it and identify that light energy has
changed to heat).

CE7270864FC944AB89E33A99DCF3C639.description:
Identify examples of energy transfers and energy transformations
(e.g., watch a machine or video where energy transfers are
occurring such as a Rube Goldberg device and identify locations
where energy is transferred or transformed).

877F4322A3104CF3A0ACFB3A4B3FF8D2.description:
Identify that some materials transfer heat energy more easily
than others (e.g., styrofoam versus metal).

63AD6910124F49499563CFFEB7D624FB.description:
Design a way to determine which materials will keep a drink hot
or cold the longest.

70F93436564C4797BC9220C6E0760256.description:
Recognize that a complete loop is need for electric energy to
flow in a circuit.

8CE55B6D6D414E25ADCDBA764CAA72B3.description:
Identify that some materials transfer electrical energy better than
others (e.g., copper versus rubber).

B155A11FB9DC40C1AF7FDF4A46C667A3.description:
Demonstrate how a complete electric circuit can cause an
energy transformation (e.g., light a bulb, ring a buzzer).

E00356ECCD794A25878B02C639165D29.description:
Demonstrate how an electromagnet shows that electricity causes
a magnetic field.

4B3A2876EB6F4EFCB8CD952D7E333B21.description:
Identify
an example of how
a type of energy
can transform
to another
type of energy
(e.g., electricity
transforms to light
energy when a
lamp is turned on).

3ED50727E9C1407181C2FF63ED4F80FB.description:
Identify
an example of
energy transfer
(e.g., the handle of
a pot on the stove
may become hot to
the touch, showing
transfer of thermal
energy from the
pot to your hand).

5607F2C4FAAF415883B427EA205E2389.description:
Demonstrate how
energy can be
transformed.

FD464F3FD1C04CF99C8FDBEC03291867.description:
Identify
examples of how
different types of
energy may be
transferred or how
different types of
energy may not be
transferred.

DD240E4B71EE457D9CD607E39337858F.description:
Describe how one
form of energy is
transformed to
another form.

4C09F56934864FE4A456AA0D5DDE9B0B.description:
Sort
objects by whether
or not they transfer
energy.

5721EA2C25894A9B90C4DE3CCF5E5734.description:
Energy can be
transferred from one
location to another or can be
transformed from one form
to another. Energy transfers
from hot objects to cold
objects as heat, resulting in a
temperature change. Electric
circuits require a complete
loop of conducting materials
through which an electrical
energy can be transferred.
Electrical energy in circuits
can be transformed to other
forms of energy, including
light, heat, sound, and motion.
Electricity and magnetism are
closely related.

F9F7E8D83601406CA43AA88740CD7FE5.description:
Watch a time lapse video of erosion or deposition in action
and identify changes that occur.

E0FE35C3199049E796E81D8D962839C0.description:
Describe the effects of water running down a pile of sand
or soil.

E6B500D0D8084E90970066888EDB4A99.description:
Recognize that erosion and deposition are processes in
nature that move Earth materials (e.g., soil, rocks).

DC835AB65D3641F49B6BDCFBCBBAEDD1.description:
List wind, water and ice as agents of erosion and
deposition.

053852FBB60A44469A495F90B042FCE1.description:
Trace the path of water in the process of erosion and
deposition.

3BEF465C6DD44480801E193CCF0C0C08.description:
Categorize changes in a landform as deposition or
erosion.

E131DD6A817641E4A525FA948E92549F.description:
Identify geologic features in Ohio (e.g., using topographic
maps or aerial photographs).

152C33F2D8D546CB88E26FD3C7691075.description:
Identify features that result from glaciers (e.g., using
Google Earth, geologic maps, pictures).

83C09BC9E4624A07926CE0618D18CD74.description:
Note: Measuring mass was introduced in 3.PS.1.Given a
natural process predict what effect it will have a particular
landform (e.g., a flood will deposit mud on roads in the
floodplain, a wind storm will blow mulch out of flowerbeds).

E7D4BFB6FCEC42DB8AB4783815F993CD.description:
Recognize that mass does not change when physical
changes occur (e.g., measure the mass before and after
breaking an object into pieces, melting ice, or rearranged
Legos into a new structure).

5A021ED22898491A857B026A2CA9B2F0.description:
Recognize that the total mass does not change when
substances are dissolved (e.g., measure the mass of
water plus salt while separated and after the salt is
dissolved in the water).

FBF8A87F9E31429BBF2622BC1B1FC051.description:
Explain why the mass before and after a change are the
same (all the same materials are still there).

D94F85F207CF45828D018F497DCEA835.description:
Given the mass before dissolving, breaking or a phase
change, predict the mass after the change.

06432D850DC04C848D81FB893F7D2626.description:
Recognize that the
mass of a given
object remains the
same before and
after a physical
change is made to
that object.

C442C4E35C364A93A5AD8213F7AF7254.description:
When given
multiple objects,
make changes to
their physical state
and measure the
mass before and
after the changes are
made to determine
conservation of mass.

F61368365F2B44048C3136F1D31FF4C8.description:
Make a
prediction about
what will happen
to the mass of
an object after a
change of state
occurs.

107E9718ECB54B5CB520CDC2C9EF46D0.description:
When objects
break into smaller pieces,
dissolve, or change state,
the total amount of matter is
conserved. When an object
is broken into smaller pieces,
when a solid is dissolved
in a liquid, or when matter
changes state (solid, liquid,
gas), the total amount of
matter remains constant.
Note: Differentiation between
mass and weight is not
necessary at this grade level.

A910737B06A94BF685EFBD2EF0EAC57A.description:
Recognize that weathering is a process in nature that changes
the shape, size and/or form of rocks.

B29DB9AE2731401AA44B8E4671B484DA.description: Identify that wind and moving water weather earth materials.

F1B0834483E741BA9E947CF46E33A0BA.description:
Watch a pothole grow throughout the winter (in the community
or time lapse video) and describe the process that is causing it
grow.

5B36F97F20F341DF9CF0AE98B02E7A63.description:
Identify that repeated freezing and thawing weathers earth
materials.

94D269A0A6FE4776976394364AAF64D3.description:
Identify types of catastrophic events (e.g., earthquakes, volcanic
eruptions, flooding)

FC20564E6CF44669AC014D5A7FBFCBFB.description:
Describe the effects that catastrophic events have on Earth’s
surface.

065ED1997A9848A18B559A8FDE984C81.description:
Categorize pictures of weathering into their causes (wind, water,
plant growth, freeze-thaw).

99670E5D0B614EC09DD96B045AC60D24.description:
Note: Introductory material about fossils can be found in 2.LS.2
for students who need an earlier entry point.Sequence a series
of pictures that illustrate weathering (e.g., sidewalk break with
plants coming through, statue wearing away due to acid rain).

8B4AD63FABB1462B8A598705E0E0BC17.description: Compare a fossil to a representation of the organism.

2071F0F986B74954AAF4AB0DDAB99934.description:
Recognize that some types of organisms that lived in the past no
longer exist.

774EB8DF4C48464B8E7BA44A1A0F2929.description:
Identify differences between pictures of extinct organisms to
modern organisms that are similar

51148ECDDAC04CFF98E77BBCBC62EFD7.description:
Match pictures of extinct organisms to modern organisms that
are similar

8E2713386AC542D58258E3A49AF91C41.description:
Recognize that environments change (compare prehistoric fossil
environments to current day environments).

7D8E54A19F6549738F981C3B96503834.description: Match a fossil to an environment where it may have lived.

11E7FE11BCA34882B751F6BBA9E7AA75.description:
Explain why we have found fossils of some animals that no
longer exist.

2507716048AA47829E0351E65D585E3D.description:
Match
a fossil with a
representation of
the organism.

6158C398DF684EDE8F92175549EFA63E.description:
Match
a fossil to an
ecosystem that it
would have lived
in.

8069CBFBDCC54318ACA733C352B8D782.description:
Given a set
of fossils and present
day organisms,
sort them by similar
characteristics.

C7CB2DF022E24D6280A413FECE8AFBA1.description:
Given
a fossil organism,
identify the prehistoric environment
it would have lived
in, and compare that
to the present day
environment where
the fossil was found.

7F9E5B81714F4FC4AFBCC796CB064596.description:
Given
a set of fossils
and present day
organisms, explain
why some fossil
organisms do not
have a present day
representative.

D53D0F010F2A427989051FB726658C53.description:
Explain
the pre-historic
environment that
a fossil organism
may have lived in
and compare that
to the present day
environment where
the fossil was
found.

A0E00ACAF7EE4A2D90C5C9494954EE21.description:
Fossils can be
compared to one another and
to present-day organisms
according to their similarities
and differences. The concept
of biodiversity is expanded to
include different classification
schemes based upon
shared internal and external
characteristics of organisms.
Most species that have lived
on Earth are extinct. Fossils
provide a point of comparison
between the types of
organisms that lived long ago
and those existing today

7F83617A739F4610B2A1CACD7FA1E357.description:
Sort pictures into categories of biotic (living) and abiotic
(nonliving).

D4AB0FE606144CFB878BCE32577BCA45.description:
List the resources in the environment that support living
things.

44F6522B35774C9A8D16CCFA536D2CD7.description:
Identify a connection between an abiotic factor and a living
organism in an environment.

040580F361F445AEAFCBEA0A4A41366F.description:
Given a series of pictures of environmental changes,
identify them as gradual or sudden.

DBC5BCBE19454AEABDE857E72D8D5D42.description:
Sort the effects of a change in an ecosystem as harmful or
beneficial to a population of organisms.

EA8D6F2116EE407EA137570E79205E61.description:
Identify given pictures of landforms and features
(mountains, volcanoes, lakes, oceans, rivers and their
floodplains, islands). Given a picture of an ecosystem
describe a change that would be beneficial to an organism
and a change that would be harmful.

ADCCCB1D645B4421BAF091174A0AB38A.description:
Match given pictures or descriptions to names of
landforms.

8ACB6F8923C642399FAE6291D4A59AA7.description:
Choose the picture of Earth which shows the correct
distribution of water and land.

59E0A54EC1AE4DBB9E0AC5DFE55FF767.description: Show on a diagram where to find ground water.

076A8D51A47F44258ED79FD176BE3013.description:
Go outside the school or watch a video and identify a
place where erosion is occurring.

E5E461BD14B8413CBDA76729CEE46C06.description: Identify agents of erosion (e.g., wind, water, ice).

7CAC453E437F4324ACA42BCCB824D588.description: Match landforms to the process that formed them.

E070EA9E5E53463D898AD6F2D54736D9.description:
Given a series of pictures showing erosion (mud washing
across a road, hill getting smaller) place them in order.

F0BA8A241F6D40278866F9F65F349267.description:
Identify products of deposition (e.g., delta forming, hill,
river bank getting bigger).

BEB5A23633084F058F4FE21963608336.description:
Given a series of pictures showing deposition (delta
forming, riverbank getting bigger) place them in order.

FE168958DB5444E889A5350E01982ACD.description:
Identify
environmental
changes as
sudden or gradual.

EE1F98CF73164C12A9E6C63738188EC0.description:
Identify
that a given
change in an
ecosystem can
be beneficial
or harmful to a
specific organism
in that ecosystem.

21837FE617F645D8868E7DBED9C28803.description:
Match
environmental
changes as sudden or
gradual.

7394AD7106B2467BA64E7086D0C4B8BA.description:
Within a
given ecosystem,
identify which
organisms would
benefit or which
organisms would
be harmed after a
change occurs.

B67C35FE64794B6A9EB74362C473D297.description:
Describe
environmental
changes that are
sudden or gradual.

71BBE39904884DE2B5DFFFF4A11D860D.description:
Given
an ecosystem,
describe changes
that could be
harmful or
beneficial to an
organism in that
ecosystem.

0EF5AB48696B48F58AF00F3C07E76AA0.description:
Changes in an
organism’s environment
are sometimes beneficial to
its survival and sometimes
harmful. Ecosystems
can change gradually or
dramatically. When the
environment changes, some
plants and animals survive
and reproduce and others
die or move to new locations.
Ecosystems are based on
interrelationships among and
between biotic and abiotic
factors. These include the
diversity of other organisms
present, the availability of
food and other resources, and
the physical attributes of the
environment.

BAED5DC7E8DF4A4495CBE5D69AC0121D.description:
Watch a time lapse video of erosion or deposition in action
and identify changes that occur.

D5CE325DC09B4B908E42C946C9DE0EEF.description:
Describe the effects of water running down a pile of sand
or soil.

2FC5C707053543AA91D70BAD14A25617.description:
Recognize that erosion and deposition are processes in
nature that move eEarth materials (e.g., soil, rocks).

4E0888E06ED14396A0EB6EAC12742967.description:
List wind, water and ice as agents of erosion and
deposition.

131D9242D9F54BAEBB5D6BC2A6A0BBFB.description:
Trace the path of water in the process of erosion and
deposition.

3745483BF3CF4790B124F2E89E80FBAC.description:
Categorize changes in a landform as deposition or
erosion.

9C6F68757BE14B239E452C4C15B63A64.description:
Identify geologic features in Ohio (e.g., using topographic
maps or aerial photographs).

90CF862D8CF54C2A8DF9BD1B3BD5B7C5.description:
Identify features that result from glaciers (e.g., using
Google Earth, geologic maps, pictures).

B1709DE6B2F9479C8FDADF56A9A1D663.description:
Given a natural process predict what effect it will have
a particular landform (e.g., a flood will deposit mud on
roads in the floodplain, a wind storm will blow mulch out of
flowerbeds).

724E15C3391A4A25BF82B77F655A0B4F.description:
Identify
natural forces that
can move rock and
soil (e.g., erosion
and deposition).

E9023192361F4EEA851E639B3B9D85E7.description:
Identify a
change in a landform
that was caused by
erosion or deposition
(e.g., formation of
valleys, sand dunes,
etc.).

862B72E2093F4A87BD2AA4AA3FDB2925.description:
Predict
the effect on a
landform when
a natural force
is introduced
(e.g., erosion and
deposition).

5650C7048D7D415084BAF39A9F71EFA0.description:
The surface of Earth
changes due to erosion and
deposition. Liquid water, wind,
and ice physically remove and
carry rock, soil, and sediment
(erosion) and deposit the
material in a new location
(deposition). Gravitational
force affects movements of
water, rock, and soil.

7A637950614947FF8B31C5F3FED15629.description:
Recognize that weathering is a process in nature that
changes the shape, size and/or form of rocks.

2D28C5254EE74311B68420A6239EB9FF.description:
Identify that wind and moving water weather earth
materials.

C8775A34B63A4D0997405F48A94EBF7D.description:
Watch a pothole grow throughout the winter (in the
community or time lapse video) and describe the process
that is causing it grow.

9C14FB0B3F644583B65F8122D23FA8F7.description:
Identify that repeated freezing and thawing weathers earth
materials.

A6F174AB40944BF6ABCAA1D08A5B3254.description:
Identify types of catastrophic events (e.g., earthquakes,
volcanic eruptions, flooding)

12EB7375F642439F86E94711C1F4A31A.description:
Describe the effects that catastrophic events have on
Earth’s surface.

3306E0AC452D42BABDFACBC7450987E8.description:
Categorize pictures of weathering into their causes (wind,
water, plant growth, freeze-thaw).

B547F35F8A6A493D81AC51FD7D053773.description:
Sequence a series of pictures that illustrate weathering
(e.g., sidewalk break with plants coming through, statue
wearing away due to acid rain).

438A5D6F69F649A48ED1864F037F14B2.description:
Match
a change in a
landform caused by
weathering to the
type of weathering
that occurred (e.g., a
crack getting larger
from water freezing).

624991783CF14C80A43256FA14841984.description:
Describe ways that
weathering (e.g.,
freezing/thawing,
plant growth,
flooding, wind, acid
rain, etc.) affects
landforms.

C6662F29DCE6460491E24E89F93945A5.description:
The surface of Earth
changes due to weathering.
Rocks change shape, size,
and/or form due to water or
glacial movement, freeze
and thaw, wind, plant growth,
acid rain, pollution, and
catastrophic events such
as earthquakes, flooding,
and volcanic activity. Note:
Differentiating between
chemical and physical
weathering is not the focus at
this grade level.

0BB9E29A370E45E3B2ECA669FEB2B71E.description:
Identify given pictures of landforms and features (e.g.,
mountains, volcanoes, lakes, oceans, rivers and their
floodplains, islands).

4E0A98EA0E11426AA8F96CC88B713FCC.description:
Match given pictures or descriptions to names of
landforms.

7F92545258DC4CF2A01EE603EC2B64ED.description:
Choose the picture of Earth which shows the correct
distribution of water and land.

39BCC3C633C748A89F931DBD3504F587.description: Show on a diagram where to find ground water.

C3050018043641AB942526CB46006810.description:
Go outside the school or watch a video and identify a
place where erosion is occurring.

2BF8A72C30FD4785A6AD00A4710FCB00.description: Identify agents of erosion (e.g., wind, water, ice).

00A61205E5EB4BAFA467BFF2B44F38D4.description: Match landforms to the process that formed them.

0A9F14FC83BB414397CF55DAEA6A658D.description:
Given a series of pictures showing erosion (mud washing
across a road, hill getting smaller) place them in order.

E83C8379752C443E84EA2208BCCAC913.description:
Identify products of deposition (e.g., delta forming, hill,
river bank getting bigger).

6F2B79750A6A41F6A63E2682DF37EDC1.description:
Given a series of pictures showing deposition (delta
forming, riverbank getting bigger) place them in order.

4592315708F44A97B09B656D58C92857.description:
Identify
a characteristic of
the Earth’s surface.

13881E0BA5DD4E519D22B9608D149A4C.description:
Match the
names of landforms
to a picture or
description.

3D926AEE9A454BF18EA52CCE06DCF257.description:
Match a
surface process to
the landform that it
creates (e.g., volcanic
activity can create an
island).

E350FC74A014495E82821362D5B8D5BE.description:
Using
a visual or actual
field observation,
describe specific
landform features.

A89D82E7704D4763B9377FD6130F1576.description:
Explain how a
surface process
has changed an
area of the Earth’s
surface.

ACF69156A93A4D0C90C27488CCC74B83.description:
Earth’s surface
has specific characteristics
and landforms that can be
identified. About 70 percent
of Earth’s surface is covered
with water, and most of that
is the ocean. Only a small
portion of Earth’s water is
freshwater, which is found in
rivers, lakes, groundwater,
and glaciers. Earth’s surface
can change due to erosion
and deposition of soil, rock, or
sediment. Catastrophic events
such as flooding, volcanic
activity, and earthquakes can
also create landforms.
